abstract.p: This course introduces students to materials genomics, treating the periodic table and all known crystal structures as a searchable, computable design space. Students learn how materials databases are built, how to represent matter as numbers, graphs, or fingerprints, how to interrogate and predict properties of solids, how to use ML as a surrogate for quantum mechanics, and how to design new materials algorithmically.

p.bold: 4th Semester – 5 ECTS · 2h lecture + 2h exercises per week, together with ML for Materials Processing & Characterization

sec.title: 2 Course Philosophy
sec.p: Materials genomics treats the periodic table and all known crystal structures as a giant searchable, computable design space.

list-item.p: how materials databases are built,
how to represent matter as numbers, graphs, or fingerprints,
how to interrogate and predict properties of solids,
how to use ML as a surrogate for quantum mechanics,
how to design new materials algorithmically.

sec.p: The angle is computational, structured, mathematically clean — the perfect foil to the messier experimental focus of other courses.

sec.title: 3.1 Unit I — Foundations of Materials Genomics (Weeks 1–3)
3.1.1 Week 1 – What is Materials Genomics?

list-item.p: Genomics analogy: genes → functions vs atoms → properties.
Brief history: AFLOW, OQMD, Materials Project, NOMAD.
PSPP from the structure-first viewpoint.

sec.p: Exercise: Explore Materials Project; query bandgaps, energies, symmetries.

sec.title: 3.1.2 Week 2 – Crystal structure fundamentals

list-item.p: Space groups, Wyckoff positions, symmetry operations.
How symmetry informs descriptors.

sec.p: Exercise: Using pymatgen / spglib to analyze symmetries.

sec.title: 3.1.3 Week 3 – Materials databases & file formats

list-item.p: CIF, POSCAR, PDB-like formats.
Thermodynamic quantities in databases: formation energy, stability, convex hull.

sec.p: Exercise: Parse CIF files, extract primitive cells, compute density.

sec.title: 3.2.1 Week 4 – Classical descriptors & materials fingerprints

list-item.p: Magpie, matminer.
Stoichiometric, elemental, and structural features.

sec.p: Exercise: Build a small property regressor with Magpie features.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Week 5 – Graph-based representations

list-item.p: Crystal structures as graphs: nodes, edges, periodic boundary conditions.
CGCNN, MEGNet architecture intuition (no training from scratch yet).

sec.p: Exercise: Build a simple CGCNN-like graph featurizer.

sec.title: 3.2.3 Week 6 – Local atomic environments

list-item.p: Voronoi tessellations, coordination numbers, SOAP descriptors.
Role in interatomic potentials and ML force fields.

sec.p: Exercise: Compute SOAP vectors; perform clustering in descriptor space.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Week 7 – Quantum mechanical data and DFT basics

list-item.p: What DFT gives you: energies, forces, band structures, elastic constants.
Why it’s expensive; why ML surrogates matter.

sec.p: Exercise: Run a toy DFT calculation (Quantum Espresso or MP workflows).

sec.title: 3.3.2 Week 8 – High-throughput workflows

list-item.p: Automation: pymatgen, custodian, FireWorks, Atomate.
Data generation for building surrogate models.

sec.p: Exercise: Perform a small FireWorks workflow (or simulate the idea without cluster resources).

sec.title: 3.3.3 Week 9 – Phase stability & the convex hull

list-item.p: Formation energies, metastability, hull distance.
Mapping an entire chemical system.

sec.p: Exercise: Reconstruct phase diagrams from Materials Project data.

sec.title: 3.4 Unit IV — Learning Properties from Atomic Structure (Weeks 10–12)
3.4.1 Week 10 – Regression on crystal data

list-item.p: Predicting bandgaps, hardness, elastic moduli.
Comparing different representation families.

sec.p: Exercise: Benchmark random forest, GPR, CGCNN on a small dataset.

sec.title: 3.4.2 Week 11 – Machine-learned interatomic potentials

list-item.p: Overview: GAP, SNAP, MTP, NequIP.
Role in simulating defects, diffusion, mechanical behavior.

sec.p: Exercise: Fit a tiny ML potential (ACE or simple SNAP-style) to toy data.

sec.title: 3.4.3 Week 12 – Generative models for materials

list-item.p: VAEs, diffusion models for crystal generation.
Constraints: symmetry, stability, charge neutrality.

sec.p: Exercise: Sample a generative model from a pretrained online source; analyze validity.

list-item.p: Predict bandgap from composition + structure representation.
Identify new stable compounds in a chemical system.
Build a graph-based model for elastic constants.
Use ML to approximate formation energies for a ternary subsystem.
Analyze SOAP fingerprints across polymorphs.
Interpreting models: SHAP for materials descriptors.
Strengths/limitations of materials genomics vs experiment-driven ML.
How computational and experimental ML meet in modern labs.

sec.title: 4 Learning Outcomes
sec.p: Students completing this course will be able to:

list-item.p: Navigate major materials databases and extract relevant structural/property data.
Represent crystals numerically using descriptors, fingerprints, and graphs.
Train ML models to predict quantum-mechanical and thermodynamic properties.
Analyze structural features via symmetry, coordination, and environments.
Perform high-throughput screening of materials candidates.
Understand and apply generative models for inorganic crystals.
Critically evaluate ML results in computational materials discovery.
